content.text: TheÂ Souzou: Outsider art from Japan exhibition gave us a wonderful opportunity to work with community groups, with its emphasis on self-expression, self-taught art techniques and simple every-day materials. Artist Daniel Wallis worked with three groups: Centre 404, St Pancras Community Centre and the Studio Art Group based at Becontree Psychotherapy Centre in Dagenham. Daniel went out to visit each group at their own 'venue' before and after their visit to Wellcome Collection so that their Souzou experience could be tailored to their specific interests and needs, and so they were meeting a familiar face when they stepped into an unfamiliar setting. Watch a short film created by Daniel about project.

We were keen to continue our links with the New Horizons Youth Centre, and asked Elaine Duigenan to develop a series of workshops inspired by Souzou to run with the Women's Group at the Centre. These proved a cathartic and liberating experience for those who took part, gradually letting go of their fear of 'doing it wrong' and opening up to each other and Elaine about their lives and challenges whilst being creative together. See a selection of photographs showing the sessions and the work produced via Flickr. Read Elaine's blog posts about the project below.

Another of our major community projects came to its exciting climax at the  Wellcome Collection Midsummer Picnic on Saturday 22 June. This year's theme was gardening and growing, with several months of projects involving the West Euston Time Bank homework club and holiday family activities programme. Over 50 volunteers from the community took part in the Picnic event, which transformed Cumberland Market into a giant garden for the c.500 people who attended. See a selection of images taken at the event  via Flickr.
The recent Souzou: Outsider art from Japan exhibition gave us a wonderful opportunity to work with community groups.
